title: 112_hr3815
content:
The Act titled "Elko Motocross and Tribal Conveyance Act" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. It involves the conveyance of land to the city and county of Elko, Nevada for the Elko Motocross Park. The Secretary will convey approximately 275 acres of land to the county of Elko, Nevada for the Elko Motocross Park. The legal description of the parcel will be finalized, and minor errors in the map or legal description can be corrected. The land conveyed for the Elko Motocross Park must be used for specific recreational purposes and public use as outlined in the Recreation and Public Purposes Act. The county is responsible for survey and administrative costs related to the land transfer. If the land conveyed for the Elko Motocross Park is no longer used for a public purpose, it may revert to the United States at the Secretary's discretion. TITLE II--ELKO INDIAN COLONY EXPANSION

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
- "Map" refers to the map titled "Te-moak Tribal Land Expansion" dated September 30, 2008, available for public inspection at the Bureau of Land Management.
- "Tribe" refers to the Te-moak Tribe of Western Shoshone Indians of Nevada, a federally recognized Indian tribe.

SEC. 202. LAND TO BE HELD IN TRUST FOR THE TE-MOAK TRIBE OF WESTERN SHOSHONE INDIANS OF NEVADA. The United States will hold trust over approximately 373 acres of land for the benefit of the Te-moak Tribe of Western Shoshone Indians of Nevada. The land will become part of the Tribe's reservation, and a survey will establish its boundaries within 180 days. Land taken into trust will not be eligible for gaming activities. The Te-moak Tribe of Western Shoshone Indians of Nevada will have approximately 373 acres of land held in trust by the United States. The land will be part of the Tribe's reservation and can only be used for traditional uses, conservation, residential, or recreational purposes. If used for other purposes, the Tribe must pay the Secretary an amount. The Te-moak Tribe of Western Shoshone Indians of Nevada will have land held in trust by the United States. The Tribe must pay the Secretary fair market value for the land. The Secretary can conduct fuels reduction and landscape restoration activities on the land in consultation with the Tribe.
